DOC.HEAD: House Speaker James Manderino Dies at 57
DOC.TEXT: State House Speaker James J. Manderino collapsed and died at his home early Tuesday, just hours before his plan to retire next year was to be announced, an aide said. He was 57. Manderino was stricken as he was getting out of bed at his home in Monessen, 25 miles south of Pittsburgh, said an aide, Charles Bacas. The cause of death was not immediately known. Bacas said he had planned to issue a statement Tuesday announcing that Manderino would retire when his 12th House term ended next December. Manderino had just completed his first year as speaker after serving previously as Democratic leader. Manderino was known for his sharp tongue and his once-immense stature. He weighed a reported 350 pounds before recently shedding more than 100 pounds. A reporter for The Philadelphia Inquirer once said of him: ``As a politician, he prefers vinegar to honey. Even his strongest political supporters don't really like him. Even his most bitter enemies respect him.'' Democratic Gov. Robert P. Casey issued a statement mourning the loss of ``a true champion.'' Manderino was ``a leader of extraordinary ability and a master of the legislative process,'' Casey said. ``He was a strong ally of this administration in working to enact programs to clean up our environment and improve our economy.'' Manderino, a lawyer, was first elected to the House in 1966. The House is scheduled to return for a token session Jan. 2 and for a voting session Jan. 22. Under state law, Majority Leader Robert O'Donnell, a Philadelphia Democrat, will serve as speaker until a replacement is elected. Manderino is survived by five children, three sisters and one brother.
